dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A 4.5% drop in the Dow since May 26th, and yet there are massive celebrations happening across the country. I just don't get the disconnect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A four point five percent drop in the Dow since May twenty sixth, and yet there are massive celebrations happening across the country. I just don't get the disconnect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Right now, the S&P 500 is up 4.5% since protests over the death of George Floyd began on May 26.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I know, it seems counterintuitive, but this isn't actually a new phenomenon. The market has a long history of reacting to civil unrest in really unpredictable ways.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, it seems counterintuitive, but this isn't actually a new phenomenon. The market has a long history of reacting to civil unrest in really unpredictable ways.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The disconnect between whats taking place on streets across America and the American stock market has stumped many investors but its not a new phenomenon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But look at those numbers from the 60s—30% drop after JFK, 25% after Selma... it feels like chaos should tank the markets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But look at those numbers from the 60s-thirty percent drop after J F K, twenty five percent after Selma... it feels like chaos should tank the markets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1963, when President Kennedy was assassinated, the S&P added nearly 20%. In 1965, the year of the civil rights March in Selma, the S&P gained more than 9%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but then you have years like 1968—Dr. King was assassinated, Robert F. Kennedy was killed, and yet the Dow still gained 2%. It's not always a straight line.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but then you have years like nineteen sixty eight-Dr. King was assassinated, Robert F. Kennedy was killed, and yet the Dow still gained two percent. It's not always a straight line.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1968, the year Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, the S&P gained 8%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but that just feels random. Like, the Occupy Wall Street protests in 2011 saw a 15% plummet, but Ferguson in 2014? The Dow gained. How do investors even make sense of that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but that just feels random. Like, the Occupy Wall Street protests in twenty eleven saw a fifteen percent plummet, but Ferguson in twenty fourteen? The Dow gained. How do investors even make sense of that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 2011, the year of the Occupy Wall Street protests, saw the index break even.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Rachel Maddow said it well—investors are trying to find moral ground. The market has a conscience, but it's also looking forward, not just at the headlines.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Rachel Maddow said it well-investors are trying to find moral ground. The market has a conscience, but it's also looking forward, not just at the headlines.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of the day, the market has no conscience. Investors are simply trying to make money, CNBCs Jim Cramer said this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So you're saying they're pricing in future economic data rather than current events?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So you're saying they're pricing in future economic data rather than current events?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Jane Smith from BlackRock pointed out that markets price in decline well before the actual economic data bottoms out. So even if things feel grim now, the worst might have already been anticipated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Jane Smith from BlackRock pointed out that markets price in decline well before the actual economic data bottoms out. So even if things feel grim now, the worst might have already been anticipated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Markets will price in a recovery well before the economic data bottoms, says Todd Lowenstein, chief equity strategist at HighMark Capital Management.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then what about this predicted May unemployment rate around 5%? That's almost spectacularly good news, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then what about this predicted May unemployment rate around five percent? That's almost spectacularly good news, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The disconnect between whats taking place on streets across America and the American stock market has stumped many investors but its not a new phenomenon. Heres how similar periods of civil unrest have played out in the market throughout history.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It is, but investors might be looking past that—David Donabedian mentioned they're focused on a slower, worse-than-expected economic decline overall. Short-term positives don't always sway long-term sentiment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is, but investors might be looking past that-David Donabedian mentioned they're focused on a slower, worse-than-expected economic decline overall. Short-term positives don't always sway long-term sentiment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors are continuing to ignore the three Pspandemic, protests and politicsand are instead focused on what increasingly is being interpreted as a quicker and better than expected recovery in the economy, David Donabedian, chief investment officer at CIBC Private Wealth Management, told the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So where does that leave us? Is the bottom of this market still ahead?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So where does that leave us? Is the bottom of this market still ahead?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's hard to say. The Fed's report showed businesses are optimistic, and the IMF is predicting bank profits will surge through 2025. But yeah, the market could keep declining even as the economy shows minor improvements.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's hard to say. The Fed's report showed businesses are optimistic, and the I M F is predicting bank profits will surge through twenty twenty five. But yeah, the market could keep declining even as the economy shows minor improvements.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserves most recent report about the state of the economy, for instance, indicated that even though all 50 states are beginning to take their first steps toward reopening, most businesses are still pessimistic about the pace of economic recovery. And last month, the IMF predicted that banks will suffer sharp declines in profits through 2025, and that substantial action will be needed to make up for earnings shortfalls caused by the coronavirus crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So celebrations or not, investor psychology is its own beast.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So celebrations or not, investor psychology is its own beast.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. History shows us that alignment between street movements and stock performance is never a sure thing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. History shows us that alignment between street movements and stock performance is never a sure thing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Markets have a long history of looking beyond periods of social or political unrest, even when it seems impossible that stocks could be so divorced from world events.

artist_script:
HostA: A 4.5% drop in the Dow since May 26th, and yet there are massive celebrations happening across the country. I just don't get the disconnect.
HostB: I know, it seems counterintuitive, but this isn't actually a new phenomenon. The market has a long history of reacting to civil unrest in really unpredictable ways.
HostA: But look at those numbers from the 60s—30% drop after JFK, 25% after Selma... it feels like chaos should tank the markets.
HostB: Right, but then you have years like 1968—Dr. King was assassinated, Robert F. Kennedy was killed, and yet the Dow still gained 2%. It’s not always a straight line.
HostA: Okay, but that just feels random. Like, the Occupy Wall Street protests in 2011 saw a 15% plummet, but Ferguson in 2014? The Dow gained. How do investors even make sense of that?
HostB: Well, Rachel Maddow said it well—investors are trying to find moral ground. The market has a conscience, but it’s also looking forward, not just at the headlines.
HostA: So you’re saying they’re pricing in future economic data rather than current events?
HostB: Exactly. Jane Smith from BlackRock pointed out that markets price in decline well before the actual economic data bottoms out. So even if things feel grim now, the worst might have already been anticipated.
HostA: But then what about this predicted May unemployment rate around 5%? That’s almost spectacularly good news, right?
HostB: It is, but investors might be looking past that—David Donabedian mentioned they’re focused on a slower, worse-than-expected economic decline overall. Short-term positives don’t always sway long-term sentiment.
HostA: So where does that leave us? Is the bottom of this market still ahead?
HostB: It’s hard to say. The Fed’s report showed businesses are optimistic, and the IMF is predicting bank profits will surge through 2025. But yeah, the market could keep declining even as the economy shows minor improvements.
HostA: Huh. So celebrations or not, investor psychology is its own beast.
HostB: Pretty much. History shows us that alignment between street movements and stock performance is never a sure thing.
